channel.title: Michael W. Kearney
channel.description: Recent content on Michael W. Kearney

item.title: About
item.description: Position I’m an assistant professor at the University of Missouri where I hold a joint appointment in Journalism Studies with the School of Journalism and in Data Science and Analytics with the Informatics Institute. I teach courses in mass media, political communication, quantitative research methods, and data science. Research My research uses computational social scientific methods to track the dissemination of information and better understand media selection behaviors in digital media environments.

item.title: Tweets about Mueller Investigation
item.description: Here’s code I used to collect a bunch of data recently. ## load rtweet library(rtweet) ## read in where left off rt <- readRDS("~/Dropbox/pgmm-all2.rds") ## search for 3 million tweets mentioning any of these keywords rt_ <- search_tweets( "papadopolous OR gates OR mueller OR manafort", n = 18000L * 10L, retryonratelimit = TRUE, max_id = max_id(rt) ) lib(warcraft) ## merge data rt <- do_call_rbind(list(rt, rt_)) ## view time series ts_plot(rt, "5 mins", trim = 1L) + theme_mwk() ## view date range range(rt$created_at) ## save saveRDS(rt, "~/Dropbox/pgmm-all2.

item.title: Twitter APIs
item.description: Twitter data gatekeeping Twitter data was already trendy, but the unpresidented 2016 U.S. election has elevated it to a fever pitch. One of the biggest drivers of the trend is the widespread, public availability of Twitter data. Twitter makes much of its user-generated data freely available to the public via Application Program Interfaces (APIs). APIs refer to sets of protocols and procedures for interacting with sites. Twitter maintains several APIs, but in the context of publicly available data collection two, in particular, stand out.
